SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: The reader can tell that Mrs. Gómez wants to

C.Choice: speak Spanish and English.

D.Choice: speak for her daughter.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrated, including the difference between first- and third-person narrations.
Content: Who tells this story to the reader?

C.Choice: Lupe Gómez

D.Choice: Claudia Gárcia

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character’s thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: What is the most likely reason that Lupe would later miss speaking English for her mother?

A.Choice: Lupe would not be able to have any more fun with her mother.

B.Choice: It has made Lupe feel needed, important, and close to her mother.

C.Choice: Lupe would no longer get to speak Spanish to her mother at home.

D.Choice: It has made it possible for Lupe to hide things from her mother.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).

C.Choice: Friends

D.Choice: Teachers

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why does Mom take Lupe to the Mexican restaurant?

A.Choice: She is repaying Lupe for speaking for her.

B.Choice: She is rewarding Lupe for getting good grades.

C.Choice: She wants to treat Lupe’s two friends to a meal.

D.Choice: She wants to give Lupe’s teacher a nice dinner.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Who helps Mrs. Gómez learn to speak English?

C.Choice: Mrs. Gárcia

D.Choice: Lupe

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrated, including the difference between first- and third-person narrations.
Content: The reader can tell that the author wanted her story to be

C.Choice: true-to-life.

D.Choice: upsetting.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character’s thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: How does Mrs. Gómez most likely feel about learning to speak English?

A.Choice: She is determined to learn English, but she understands that it will be difficult.

B.Choice: She is learning English only so Lupe will not have to go everywhere with her.

C.Choice: She is learning English only because she needs it to be able to live in Chicago.

D.Choice: She is angry that she cannot use her native language all the time.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character’s thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: How does Lupe show respect for her mother at the end of the story?

A.Choice: She tells her mother that it will take her a long time to learn English.

B.Choice: She asks her mother questions in English so she can practice.

C.Choice: She asks her mother to tell her what she would do without her.

D.Choice: She tells her mother she will miss translating and says, “Buenas noches.”

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: What is the central idea in this article?

A.Choice: The frog’s poison is powerful and useful.

B.Choice: Predators retreat when they meet the tiny and beautiful frog.

C.Choice: The frog lives deep in the rain forest.

D.Choice: Darts dipped in the frog’s poison are used as weapons.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.

C.Choice: dead body.

D.Choice: dry stick.

B.Choice: study the effects of the frog’s poison.

C.Choice: trap dangerous snakes.

D.Choice: hunt with darts dipped in the frog’s poison.

C.Choice: How does the frog make its poison?

D.Choice: What enemies does the frog have?

SubTopics: Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account, including those by or about Minnesota American Indians, of the same event or topic; describe the differences in focus and the information provided.
Content: The author most likely wrote this article to

A.Choice: introduce readers to the Embera Choco people of Colombia.

B.Choice: persuade readers to visit the rain forest of Colombia.

C.Choice: inform readers about a deadly animal that lives in South America.

D.Choice: warn readers to avoid a dangerous animal that lives in South America.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement is a main idea of the poem?

C.Choice: Libraries are usually closed at night.

D.Choice: Libraries are great places to spend time.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.

C.Choice: Digging around in a box of books

D.Choice: Shining bright lights at each other

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the article shows bats as caring animals?

A.Choice: “Disease and human beings are threats to bats.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “Even with their wings, bats are some of the smallest mammals on Earth.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “As seen in books, bats do hang upside down by their feet.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “Bats even provide food for the sick among them.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence is the best summary of paragraph 5?

A.Choice: Bats can search the ground and locate prey while they fly.

B.Choice: Bats can make a meal out of anything they catch in the dark.

C.Choice: Bats must have good eyesight and good hearing to find food.

D.Choice: Bats must be able to see in the dark because they are active at night.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: What information from the article supports the fact that bats are mammals?

A.Choice: Bats have thumbs and can hang upside down.

B.Choice: Bats have fur and can nurse their young.

C.Choice: Bats have skin that covers their wings.

D.Choice: Bats have faces that look like mice.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Read line 3 from “Bats at the Library.”
:box:We’ve feasted, fluttered, swooped, and soared,
Which paragraph in “Creatures of the Night” shows how the bats “feasted”?

C.Choice: Paragraph 6

D.Choice: Paragraph 7

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: The article helps readers understand the setting of the poem by explaining why bats

C.Choice: like only cool weather.

D.Choice: rest only while hanging upside down.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement is supported by details in both the article and the poem?

A.Choice: Bats live in groups that spend time together.

B.Choice: Bats hunt with one another for food at night.

C.Choice: Bats play a part in helping plants grow.

D.Choice: Bats look for food whenever possible.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement is true about both the article and the poem?

A.Choice: “Creatures of the Night” suggests that bats and humans can live together, but “Bats at the Library” suggests that bats cannot live around humans.

B.Choice: “Creatures of the Night” shows the frightening side of bats, but “Bats at the Library” shows the friendly side of bats.

C.Choice: “Creatures of the Night” describes how bats look, but “Bats at the Library” contains no descriptions of bats.

D.Choice: “Creatures of the Night” contains information about bats, but“ Bats at the Library” uses bats as characters in a story.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast a firsthand and secondhand account, including those by or about Minnesota American Indians, of the same event or topic; describe the differences in focus and the information provided.
Content: Based on the article and the poem, the author and the poet most likely agree that bats

C.Choice: help people in many ways.

D.Choice: are smarter than other creatures.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which paragraph in the article describes a problem without offering a solution?

C.Choice: Paragraph 4

D.Choice: Paragraph 5

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which sentence from the article supports the idea that bats are useful?

A.Choice: “Bats have four slender fingers and a thin skin that stretches from finger to finger to form each wing.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “This nail helps the bat cling to various surfaces and hold onto its food.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “A keen eye is necessary for a bat, which can fly hundreds of feet above the ground looking for a good meal.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “These bats later transfer pollen to other plants or drop seeds that will grow into more fruit-bearing plants.” (paragraph 6)

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How is the information in paragraph 9 presented?

A.Choice: The author uses a problem-and-solution approach to show how people can enjoy nature.

B.Choice: The author uses a cause-and-effect approach to show how bats help animals and people.

C.Choice: The author uses comparison to show how bats depend on plants and animals to live.

D.Choice: The author uses ordered steps to show how people can protect plants and animals.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: According to the author of “Creatures of the Night,” bats are in danger of vanishing because

B.Choice: they are only able to fly at night.

C.Choice: they remain in large colonies for most of their lives.

D.Choice: they are some of the smallest mammals in the world.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character’s thoughts, words, or actions).

A.Choice: Excited about leaving the library for home

B.Choice: Frightened by the light growing in the distance

C.Choice: Hopeful about visiting the library again in the future

D.Choice: Angry to be interrupted while having a good time
